Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Narrating Disaster: Calibrating Causality and Responses to the 2015 Earthquakes in Nepal

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The immediate research response to a natural disaster frequently focuses on loss of life, injuries, structural damage, and aid response. Research on the demographic shifts associated with response efforts and the social, linguistic, and economic effects of 'outsiders' engaging with affected communities is often overlooked. Without immediate action to capture and document these details, the individual experiences of people who survived these events risks being merged into more generalized narratives, influenced and homogenized by media reports. The possibility of this disconnect was brought to the fore during events such as Hurricanes Andrew in 1992 and Katrina in 2005, where initial media coverage under-represented individual and local experiences, but where subsequent ethnographic studies found practical and pedagogical value in capturing such details (for example, the lived effects of the privatization of health and housing services, and the construction of culturally sensitive science curriculum materials about hurricanes).

This project focuses on Nepal, which was recently devastated by major earthquakes in April and May 2015, to capture individual-level and local experiences in a timely manner. The researchers will collect, annotate, and make publicly available interviews and narratives conducted with earthquake survivors. The geo-linguistic focus will be communities of Tibeto-Burman language-speaking peoples from three districts of Nepal's Western Zone: Mustang, Manang and Gorkha, including local residents and former residents (rural-urban migrants) who are now moving back to their home villages to participate in relief and rebuilding efforts. All are speakers of endangered languages. Linguists Kristine Hildebrandt of the Southern Illinois University, Edwardsville and Mark Donahue of Australian National University along with Medical Anthropologist Sienna Craig of Dartmouth College and Cultural Anthropologist Geoff Childs will work with Nepali researchers to elicit narratives and interview speakers to build a database of survivor narratives, one that takes the perspective of the survivors and responders. The narratives will reveal grammatical and discourse features of emotive language. These materials will also reveal nuances about the relationship between humans and their social and physical environment while the collective memory of the event is still fresh, providing valuable insider perspectives on why and how people create and maintain their livelihoods in places and in ways where extreme environmental conditions are a constant and powerful presence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation Documenting Endangered Languages program funded project BCS 1547377 "RAPID: Narrating Disaster: Calibrating Causality and Responses to the 2015 Earthquakes in Nepal." The primary goal of the project was to collect, annotate, and make publicly available interviews and narratives conducted with Tibeto-Burman language speaking survivors of the 2015 Nepal earthquakes. With these materials, we aimed to build a corpus that takes the perspective of survivors and responders, all hailing from diverse ethnic, socioeconomic, and educational backgrounds, but all sharing a significant common variable: their experiences of these earthquakes and their aftershocks. Another goal was to employ participatory methods in order to train local (native language-speaking) representatives, empowering them to be personally invested and involved in the fieldwork and data analysis. The methods contributing to these goals and outputs therefore provided for community and also student collaboration and training in methods of data collection, processing, and materials archival process.

 The initial phase of the project involved training local language community members in aspects of fieldwork and data collection through A-V recordings in areas of Nepal impacted by the earthquakes, including ethical practices that involved informed consent. Upon completion of fieldwork, at the home institution, the students worked with the Co-I's and with collaborators at a field office in Nepal to transcribe materials and prepare them for archive at the University of Virginia's Tibetan and Himalayan Digital Library. The students also worked with the Co-I's to build a second custom archival application at the home institution to house data and project outputs in digital form. Three undergraduate students participated in building digital materials and co-authoring conference presentations and publications via two NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) supplements. Additional undergraduate students volunteered to assist with work on transcription.

 The intellectual merit of this project includes the creation of a corpus of interviews and narratives. This corpus is archived online, in an open and searchable format, and the content has added to the knowledge base of factors behind language practices, vitality and vulnerability in areas of great change and population movement. The interviews have also provided updated demographic and ethno-linguistic profiles of these regions. The transcribed and translated texts have provided rich linguistic data towards publications on linguistic dimensions of agency, on causality, and on consequences of surviving a traumatic event such as a natural catastrophe. The transcribed materials have provided information towards publications on the linguistic encoding of evidence, on other phenomena not typically encountered in standard reference grammars or dictionaries (cultural and religious references and onomatopoeia, for example).

The broader impacts include formal training to community members in Nepal on fieldwork methods. Some of the researchers have parlayed this and related research experiences with the PI and Co-PIs into full-time research positions and other employment opportunities. In this way, the collaborative methods have derived tangible and long-term professional benefits to many participants. The impacts also include informal and formal training and mentoring to undergraduate university students on digital materials organization and processing, and on the use of these materials in their own scholarly projects that cross disciplines. Students also received professionalism training by their involvement in community networking, conference participation, and manuscript construction and revision.

 The resulting products and outcomes include several conference presentations and published manuscripts/articles/chapters that are of interest to broad audiences, within and beyond academia. Also included are online archives, in which project materials and derivatives are catalogued, and which are open to any interested users.

Beyond the academic and community value, the project methods also included professional training and mentorship for several students at the home institution. Over the long term, this project will enable collaborators to continue working with materials towards ongoing publications and outputs. The transcribed and translated archive will serve as a valuable conduit of language practices and information about community traditions and their histories in the context of the human response to large-scale events such as natural catastrophes.
